Climate targets from national laws or policies pose a challenge for policymakers and researchers, limiting their ability to assess alignment with global goals and inform policy decisions. This paper presents an approach for extracting mentions of climate targets from national laws and policies. We create an expert-annotated dataset with three categories of targets: 'Net Zero', 'Reduction', and 'Other' (e.g., renewable energy targets). We train a classifier to reliably identify these targets in text and investigate bias and equity impacts related to our model. We also identify specific years and country names as problematic features. Our work demonstrates the potential for automated data collection and research support in climate policy. 

Climate law and policy are a primary lever for national and international climate action. Targets, which are quantified, measurable expressions of prospective policy outcomes, are a cornerstone of effective climate policy. Targets bolster the credibility of countries' commitments by setting quantifiable objectives and inform policy design, implementation, and monitoring. Data on existing targets addressing climate change is invaluable for policy analysis, and actors engaged in the design or evaluation of national laws and policies often look to targets as a first point of reference to establish national and international progress and ambition in addressing climate change.

Analysis of existing laws and policies is constrained by limited resources and expertise. Common barriers include: (1) key information buried within lengthy, difficult-to-parse documents, and (2) policies and targets written in many different languages and terminologies. These constraints affect all actors working to understand and improve the efficacy of climate laws and policies, including policymakers, academics, NGOs, and UN bodies, and are especially acute for those operating under resource constraints, including in low-income countries and communities.

We present an approach for extracting mentions of targets from national climate laws and policies using paragraph-level classification. Our model and related dataset are available online. We explore the dataset generated from applying our classifier to the Climate Policy Radar (CPR) dataset, showcasing the potential for automated data collection and research support in climate policy. Our work represents a significant upgrade in the accessibility of key climate policy elements for policymakers and researchers.

Existing databases, including Net Zero Tracker, Climate Change Laws of the World, Climate Policy Radar, ClimateWatch, and Climate Action Tracker, rely on manual extraction of targets, limiting their scalability and consuming significant organisational resources. Many of these databases only collect targets from Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) and focus on economy-wide targets, neglecting other types of targets like sectoral targets. This results in a fundamental gap in the analysis of global public and private sector commitments.

Natural Language Processing (NLP) has been applied to extract climate-related targets before, but without addressing individual greenhouse gases (GHGs) or economic sectors. Our work extends existing contributions by: (1) extending the definitions of emissions reduction and net-zero targets to include those addressing individual GHGs and sectors of the economy; (2) introducing a new 'Other' category of targets to capture quantified targets made by governments with mitigation or adaptation objectives that do not explicitly mention emissions reduction; and (3) curating a multi-label dataset, enabling each instance to be associated with zero, one, or multiple designated categories.

The data was sourced from the Climate Policy Radar (CPR) database and UNFCCC submissions containing over 4,000 documents published by every single national government. We assign the target types 'Net Zero', 'Reduction', or 'Other' to paragraphs in a multi-label classification setting. A target satisfies three criteria: it (1) contains an aim to achieve a specific outcome, (2) is quantifiable, and (3) has been given a deadline. We consider targets set by governments focusing on their specific national objectives and actions, rather than regional or global goals. Reduction targets refer to a reduction of emissions.
